title: Jupyter Notebook Fundamentals
description: From IPython (2001) to JupyterLab 4 (2025) - The interactive environment for Data Science, scientific research, and executable documentation

slides.title: Jupyter Notebook
slides.subtitle: Interactive Computing & Literate Programming
slides.description: From IPython (2001) to JupyterLab 4 (2025) - Code, documentation, and visualizations in a single document
slides.ironicClosing: Jupyter: where code and prose meet. Excel for data scientists? More or less.

slides.title: üìú The History of Jupyter
paragraphs: 2001: IPython (Fernando P√©rez) - Enhanced interactive Python shell
2011: IPython Notebook - Web-based notebook (precursor to Jupyter)
2014: Project Jupyter - Spin-off from IPython, multiple languages
Name: Ju(lia) + Pyt(hon) + R = Jupyter (3 core languages)
Today: De-facto standard for Data Science, Machine Learning, scientific research
Used by: Netflix, NASA, Bloomberg, Google, CERN, universities worldwide
slides.ironicClosing: From Python shell to global platform. IPython: 'hold my beer, I'll change science'.

slides.title: üöÄ Jupyter 2025: Current Versions
paragraphs: ‚Ä¢ IDE-like interface with tabs, split view, file browser
‚Ä¢ Perfect for beginners or simple use
Recommendation: JupyterLab 4 for serious use, Notebook 7 for simplicity
slides.ironicClosing: JupyterLab vs Notebook: IDE vs text editor. Both valid, choose your fighter.

slides.title: Why Jupyter?
paragraphs: Literate Programming: Code + documentation + visualizations in a single document
Interactivity: Run code cell by cell, see results immediately
Data exploration: Test code, experiment, iterate quickly
Multi-language: Python, R, Julia, JavaScript, SQL, +40 kernels
Sharing: .ipynb format, nbviewer, GitHub rendering, export PDF/HTML
‚Ä¢ Data Science, Machine Learning, Data Analysis
slides.ironicClosing: Jupyter: PowerPoint that runs code. Or Word with superpowers. Choose your metaphor.

slides.title: Setup: Install Jupyter
slides.ironicClosing: Installation: one command. Startup: one command. Productivity: endless hours wasted making pretty charts.

slides.title: üíª Quick Start: First Notebook

code.snippet:
# Installazione
pip install jupyterlab

# Avviare JupyterLab
jupyter lab

# O Notebook classic
jupyter notebook

# Avvia su porta specifica
jupyter lab --port=8889

# Avvia senza aprire browser
jupyter lab --no-browser

# Avvia in directory specifica
cd /path/to/project
jupyter lab

# ===== Creare primo notebook =====
# 1. Click "New" ‚Üí "Notebook"
# 2. Scegli kernel (Python 3)
# 3. Prima cella:
print("Hello, Jupyter!")

# 4. Esegui: Shift+Enter
# Output: Hello, Jupyter!

# Salvare: Cmd+S (Mac) o Ctrl+S (Win/Linux)
# File salvato come: Untitled.ipynb

slides.explanation: jupyter lab to start. Shift+Enter to execute cells. .ipynb is the format.

slides.title: Jupyter Interface
slides.subtitle: Cells, toolbar, kernel, shortcuts
slides.description: Navigating and using the Jupyter interface effectively

slides.title: Anatomy of a Notebook
paragraphs: ‚Ä¢ JSON format that contains cells, output, metadata
‚Ä¢ Versionable with git (but watch out for the outputs)
‚Ä¢ Process Python (or another language) that executes code
‚Ä¢ Save, Insert, Cut, Copy, Paste cells
slides.ironicClosing: Kernel: the brain. Cells: the neurons. You: the confused neuroscientist debugging.

slides.title: üíª Essential Keyboard Shortcuts

code.snippet:
# ===== COMMAND MODE (blu, ESC per attivare) =====
A          # Insert cell Above
B          # Insert cell Below
DD         # Delete cell (D due volte)
Z          # Undo delete
M          # Converti a Markdown
Y          # Converti a Code
C          # Copy cell
V          # Paste cell below
X          # Cut cell

Shift+Up/Down    # Seleziona celle multiple
Shift+M          # Merge celle selezionate

# Esecuzione
Shift+Enter      # Run cell, seleziona next
Ctrl+Enter       # Run cell, rimani su corrente
Alt+Enter        # Run cell, insert below

# ===== EDIT MODE (verde, ENTER per attivare) =====
Tab              # Autocomplete o indent
Shift+Tab        # Tooltip/documentation
Ctrl+]           # Indent
Ctrl+[           # Dedent
Cmd+/            # Toggle comment (Mac)
Ctrl+/           # Toggle comment (Win/Linux)

# ===== GLOBAL =====
Cmd+S / Ctrl+S   # Save notebook
ESC              # Command mode
ENTER            # Edit mode
H                # Help (mostra tutti shortcuts)

slides.explanation: Shift+Enter to execute. A/B to insert cells. M/Y for type. H for help.

slides.title: üíª Kernel Management

code.snippet:
# Kernel mantiene stato tra celle

# Cella 1
x = 10
y = 20

# Cella 2 (eseguita dopo)
print(x + y)  # Output: 30 (x e y esistono!)

# Cella 3
import numpy as np
arr = np.array([1, 2, 3])

# Cella 4 (eseguita dopo)
print(arr * 2)  # Output: [2 4 6] (numpy importato)

# ===== Comandi Kernel =====
# Toolbar ‚Üí Kernel ‚Üí Restart
# Toolbar ‚Üí Kernel ‚Üí Restart & Clear Output
# Toolbar ‚Üí Kernel ‚Üí Restart & Run All

# ‚ö†Ô∏è Ordine esecuzione conta!
# Se esegui celle fuori ordine, stato pu√≤ essere inconsistente

# Best practice:
# - Restart & Run All periodicamente (verifica tutto funziona)
# - Numeri [1], [2], [3] a sinistra = ordine esecuzione

slides.explanation: Kernel = persistent state. Restart to reset. Execution order matters!

slides.title: üíª Output & Display

code.snippet:
# Output automatico (ultima espressione) x = 5 y = 10 x + y # Output: 15 # Print esplicito print("Risultato:", x + y) print("Altro output") # Output: # Risultato: 15 # Altro output # Multiple outputs from IPython.display import display x = 10 display(x) display(x * 2) display(x * 3) # Output: 10, 20, 30 (tutti visibili) # Rich display from IPython.display import HTML, Markdown, Image, Video # HTML display(HTML('

Hello Jupyter

')) # Markdown display(Markdown('**Bold** and *italic*')) # Image display(Image('path/to/image.png')) # Video display(Video('path/to/video.mp4')) # LaTeX from IPython.display import Math display(Math(r'\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^n x_i^2'))

slides.explanation: Last auto-displayed expression. display() for multiple. Rich display for HTML/images.

slides.title: üíª Autocomplete & Help

code.snippet:
import numpy as np

# ===== AUTOCOMPLETE (Tab) =====
# Scrivi: np.ar<TAB>
# Mostra: array, arange, arccos, arcsin, ...

# Metodi oggetto
arr = np.array([1, 2, 3])
# Scrivi: arr.<TAB>
# Mostra: shape, dtype, mean, sum, ...

# ===== DOCUMENTATION (Shift+Tab) =====
# Cursore su funzione, Shift+Tab
np.array()  # Shift+Tab ‚Üí mostra docstring

# Shift+Tab x 2 volte ‚Üí expanded doc
# Shift+Tab x 4 volte ‚Üí doc in pane separato

# ===== HELP (?  e ??) =====
np.array?   # Mostra docstring (equivalente a help())
np.array??  # Mostra source code (se disponibile)

# Help su oggetto
arr = np.array([1, 2, 3])
arr?  # Info su arr

# ===== dir() per esplorare =====
dir(np)  # Lista tutti attributi/metodi di numpy

# ===== type() e isinstance() =====
type(arr)  # <class 'numpy.ndarray'>
isinstance(arr, np.ndarray)  # True

slides.explanation: Tab for autocomplete. Shift+Tab for docs. ? for help. ?? for source.

slides.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è Common Beginner Mistakes
paragraphs: Fix: Restart & Run All to verify
Code written but not executed ‚Üí variables do not exist
Fix: Shift+Enter to execute each cell
Cell in infinite execution (loop, slow operation)
4. Huge output that slows down the notebook
Print of giant arrays, loop that prints thousands of lines
Fix: Clear output, limit print, use head()/tail()
Jupyter autosaves, but it's better to save manually.
Fix: Clear output before commit, or use nbstripout
slides.ironicClosing: Jupyter: 'cell [*]' means 'go grab a coffee'. Or 'you have an infinite loop'.

slides.title: üíª Markdown Basics

code.snippet:
# Heading 1
## Heading 2
### Heading 3

**Bold text**
*Italic text*
~~Strikethrough~~

- Bullet list
- Item 2
  - Nested item

1. Numbered list
2. Item 2
3. Item 3

[Link text](https://example.com)

![Image alt text](path/to/image.png)

`Inline code`

```python

    print("Hello")
```

> Blockquote
> Multiple lines

---
Horizontal rule

| Column 1 | Column 2 | Column 3 |
|----------|----------|----------|
| Value 1  | Value 2  | Value 3  |
| Value 4  | Value 5  | Value 6  |

slides.explanation: Markdown for documentation. # for headings, ** for bold, - for lists.

slides.title: üíª LaTeX for Mathematics

code.snippet:
<!-- Inline math con $ $ -->
La formula di Eulero: $e^{i\pi} + 1 = 0$

Pitagora: $a^2 + b^2 = c^2$

<!-- Display math con $$ $$ -->
Gradiente discesa:
$$
\theta_{t+1} = \theta_t - \alpha \nabla J(\theta_t)
$$

Regressione lineare:
$$
y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + \epsilon
$$

Normal distribution:
$$
f(x | \mu, \sigma^2) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}} e^{-\frac{(x-\mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}}
$$

Matrice:
$$
\begin{bmatrix}
a & b \\
c & d
\end{bmatrix}
$$

Sommatoria:
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i = x_1 + x_2 + \cdots + x_n
$$

Integrale:
$$
\int_{a}^{b} f(x) dx
$$

slides.explanation: LaTeX for formulas. $ inline, $$ display. Standard LaTeX syntax.

slides.title: üíª HTML & Styling in Markdown

code.snippet:
Testo rosso e grassetto
üí° Nota: Questo √® un box informativo

Random Forest 0.92 0.89

slides.title: üíª Professional Notebook Structure

code.snippet:
# Titolo Analisi: Predizione Prezzi Case

**Autore:** Nome Cognome  
**Data:** 2025-11-18  
**Versione:** 1.0

---

## üìã Table of Contents
1. [Introduzione](#intro)
2. [Dataset](#dataset)
3. [Analisi Esplorativa](#eda)
4. [Feature Engineering](#features)
5. [Modeling](#modeling)
6. [Risultati](#results)
7. [Conclusioni](#conclusions)

---

## 1. Introduzione {#intro}

### Obiettivo
Predire il prezzo di vendita delle case basandosi su features come...

### Metodologia
- Dataset: Kaggle House Prices
- Modelli: Linear Regression, Random Forest, XGBoost
- Metrica: RMSE

---

## 2. Dataset {#dataset}

### Source
...

<!-- Poi celle code con pandas.read_csv(), df.head(), etc. -->

slides.explanation: Professional structure: Title, TOC, sections, markdown + alternating code.

slides.title: üíª Emojis & Icons for Readability

code.snippet:
# üìä Data Analysis Workflow

## üì• 1. Data Loading
- ‚úÖ Load CSV
- ‚úÖ Check shape
- ‚úÖ Inspect dtypes

## üîç 2. Exploratory Data Analysis
- üìà Distribution plots
- üîó Correlation matrix
- üó∫Ô∏è Geographic visualization

## üõ†Ô∏è 3. Data Preprocessing
- üßπ Handle missing values
- üî¢ Encode categoricals
- üìè Scale features

## ü§ñ 4. Modeling
- üå≤ Random Forest
- üöÄ XGBoost
- üß† Neural Network

## üìä 5. Results
- ‚úÖ Best model: XGBoost
- üìà RMSE: 0.12
- ‚≠ê Feature importance

## üí° Key Insights
- üè† Square footage √® il predictor pi√π importante
- üìç Location √® cruciale
- ‚ö†Ô∏è Outliers influenzano molto il modello

## ‚ö†Ô∏è Limitations
## üöÄ Next Steps
## üìö References

slides.explanation: Emojis for scanability. Icons make sections immediately recognizable.

slides.title: Best Practices Markdown
paragraphs: # for main title, ## for sections, ### for subsections
Table of contents with internal links (#anchors)
Markdown to explain, code to execute (no code in markdown cells)
Useful for scanability, but don't overdo it (professionalism)
Highlight important information with colored boxes.
Markdown cells before complex code to explain logic
Author, date, version in the header
slides.ironicClosing: Markdown: makes your notebooks look professional. Even if the code is a disaster.

slides.title: Magic Commands
slides.subtitle: IPython magic for superpowers
slides.description: Line magics (%) and cell magics (%%) for productivity

slides.title: üíª Line Magics (%)

code.snippet:
# ===== TIMING =====
%time sum(range(1000000))  # Tempo singola esecuzione
%timeit sum(range(1000000))  # Media multiple esecuzioni (pi√π accurato)

# ===== WORKING DIRECTORY =====
%pwd  # Print working directory
%cd /path/to/directory  # Change directory
%ls   # List files

# ===== SHELL COMMANDS (!) =====
!pip install pandas  # Esegui comando shell
!ls -la              # List files dettagliato
!git status          # Git commands

# Cattura output
files = !ls
print(files)  # Lista file

# ===== ENVIRONMENT =====
%env  # Mostra env variables
%env MY_VAR=value  # Set env variable

# ===== HISTORY =====
%history  # Mostra history comandi
%history -n 1-5  # Mostra comandi 1-5

# ===== RUN SCRIPT =====
%run script.py  # Esegui script Python
%run -i script.py  # Run in current namespace

# ===== LOAD CODE =====
%load script.py  # Carica script in cella (non esegue)

slides.explanation: Line magics: % prefix. %time, %timeit, !shell, %run. Very useful.

slides.title: üíª Cell Magics (%%)

code.snippet:
# ===== %%time / %%timeit ===== # Time intera cella %%time import numpy as np arr = np.random.randn(1000000) result = arr.mean() %%timeit # Average time su multiple runs import numpy as np arr = np.random.randn(1000) result = arr.mean() # ===== %%writefile ===== # Scrive contenuto cella in file %%writefile script.py def hello(): print("Hello from script!") if __name__ == '__main__': hello() # ===== %%bash ===== # Esegui comandi bash %%bash echo "Hello from bash" ls -la pwd # ===== %%html ===== # Render HTML %%html

HTML Header

Paragraph text

# ===== %%javascript ===== # Esegui JavaScript %%javascript alert('Hello from JavaScript!'); # ===== %%latex ===== # Render LaTeX %%latex \begin{align} x &= y + z \\ a &= b + c \end{align}

slides.explanation: Cell magics: %% prefix. Entire cell. %%time, %%writefile, %%bash, %%html.

slides.title: üíª Debug & Profiling

code.snippet:
# ===== %debug =====
# Dopo eccezione, entra in debugger
def buggy_function():
    x = 10
    y = 0
    return x / y  # ZeroDivisionError

buggy_function()
%debug  # Entra in pdb debugger interattivo

# ===== %pdb =====
# Auto-debug su eccezioni
%pdb on   # Abilita auto-debug
%pdb off  # Disabilita

# ===== %prun =====
# Profiler (quali funzioni pi√π lente)
%prun slow_function()

# ===== %%prun =====
%%prun
# Profile intera cella
import numpy as np
for i in range(100):
    arr = np.random.randn(10000)
    result = arr.mean()

# ===== %lprun (line profiler, serve line_profiler package) =====
%load_ext line_profiler
%lprun -f function_name function_name(args)

# ===== %memit (memory profiler) =====
%load_ext memory_profiler
%memit arr = np.random.randn(1000000)

slides.explanation: %debug for debugging. %prun for profiling. %memit for memory usage.

slides.title: üíª Matplotlib Integration

code.snippet:
# ===== %matplotlib inline =====
# Grafici inline nel notebook (default)
%matplotlib inline
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.plot([1, 2, 3, 4])
plt.ylabel('values')
plt.show()

# ===== %matplotlib notebook =====
# Grafici interattivi (zoom, pan)
%matplotlib notebook
plt.plot([1, 2, 3, 4])
plt.show()

# ===== %matplotlib widget =====
# Grafici interattivi moderni (ipympl)
# pip install ipympl
%matplotlib widget
plt.plot([1, 2, 3, 4])
plt.show()

# ===== %config InlineBackend =====
# Configura backend inline
%config InlineBackend.figure_format = 'retina'  # High-res su Retina
%config InlineBackend.figure_format = 'svg'     # SVG (scalable)
%config InlineBackend.figure_format = 'png'     # PNG (default)

# Resolution
%config InlineBackend.rc = {'figure.dpi': 150}

slides.explanation: %matplotlib inline for static plots. %matplotlib widget for interactive ones.

slides.title: üíª Useful Magic Commands

code.snippet:
# ===== %who / %whos =====
%who      # Lista variabili correnti
%who int  # Solo variabili tipo int
%whos     # Dettagli (type, data/info)

# ===== %reset =====
%reset    # Clear tutte le variabili (chiede conferma)
%reset -f # Force reset (no conferma)

# ===== %xdel =====
x = [1, 2, 3] * 1000000  # Large object
%xdel x  # Delete + garbage collect

# ===== %quickref =====
%quickref  # Quick reference IPython

# ===== %lsmagic =====
%lsmagic  # Lista tutti magic commands disponibili

# ===== %notebook =====
%notebook filename.ipynb  # Export sessione a notebook

# ===== %recall =====
%recall 5  # Richiama output cella 5

# ===== %rerun =====
%rerun 5  # Re-esegui cella 5

# ===== %macro =====
%macro name 1-5  # Crea macro da celle 1-5
name  # Esegui macro

slides.explanation: %who to see variables. %reset to clear. %lsmagic for a complete list.

slides.title: Views
slides.subtitle: Matplotlib, Seaborn, Plotly, Altair
slides.description: Static and Interactive Graphs in Jupyter

slides.title: üíª Matplotlib: Basics

code.snippet:
%matplotlib inline
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Line plot
x = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)
y = np.sin(x)

plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(x, y, label='sin(x)', linewidth=2)
plt.plot(x, np.cos(x), label='cos(x)', linewidth=2, linestyle='--')
plt.xlabel('x')
plt.ylabel('y')
plt.title('Trigonometric Functions')
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
plt.show()

# Scatter plot
x = np.random.randn(100)
y = np.random.randn(100)
colors = np.random.rand(100)

plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))
plt.scatter(x, y, c=colors, s=50, alpha=0.6, cmap='viridis')
plt.colorbar()
plt.xlabel('X')
plt.ylabel('Y')
plt.title('Scatter Plot')
plt.show()

# Subplots
fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 2, figsize=(12, 10))
axes[0, 0].plot(x, y)
axes[0, 1].hist(x, bins=20)
axes[1, 0].scatter(x, y)
axes[1, 1].bar([1, 2, 3], [10, 20, 15])
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

slides.explanation: Matplotlib: base library. plot(), scatter(), hist(), subplots(). Very flexible.

slides.title: üíª Seaborn: Statistical Plots

code.snippet:
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

# Set style
sns.set_style('whitegrid')
sns.set_palette('husl')

# Sample data
tips = sns.load_dataset('tips')

# Distribution plot
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
sns.histplot(tips['total_bill'], kde=True, bins=30)
plt.title('Distribution of Total Bill')
plt.show()

# Box plot
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
sns.boxplot(x='day', y='total_bill', hue='sex', data=tips)
plt.title('Total Bill by Day and Sex')
plt.show()

# Violin plot
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
sns.violinplot(x='day', y='total_bill', data=tips)
plt.show()

# Correlation heatmap
iris = sns.load_dataset('iris')
corr = iris.corr(numeric_only=True)
plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))
sns.heatmap(corr, annot=True, cmap='coolwarm', center=0)
plt.title('Correlation Matrix')
plt.show()

# Pairplot
sns.pairplot(iris, hue='species')
plt.show()

slides.explanation: Seaborn: high-level interface. Statistical plots. histplot, boxplot, heatmap.

slides.title: üíª Plotly: Interactive Plots

code.snippet:
import plotly.express as px
import plotly.graph_objects as go
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

# Scatter plot interattivo
df = px.data.iris()
fig = px.scatter(
    df, 
    x='sepal_width', 
    y='sepal_length',
    color='species',
    size='petal_length',
    hover_data=['petal_width'],
    title='Iris Dataset'
)
fig.show()

# Line plot con range slider
dates = pd.date_range('2024-01-01', periods=100)
values = np.cumsum(np.random.randn(100))

fig = go.Figure()
fig.add_trace(go.Scatter(x=dates, y=values, mode='lines'))
fig.update_xaxes(rangeslider_visible=True)
fig.update_layout(title='Time Series with Range Slider')
fig.show()

# 3D Scatter
fig = px.scatter_3d(
    df,
    x='sepal_length',
    y='sepal_width',
    z='petal_length',
    color='species'
)
fig.show()

# Heatmap interattiva
z = np.random.randn(20, 20)
fig = go.Figure(data=go.Heatmap(z=z, colorscale='Viridis'))
fig.show()

slides.explanation: Plotly: interactive plots. Zoom, pan, hover tooltips. Great for exploration.

slides.title: üíª Pandas Plotting

code.snippet:
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Sample DataFrame
df = pd.DataFrame({
    'A': np.random.randn(100).cumsum(),
    'B': np.random.randn(100).cumsum(),
    'C': np.random.randn(100).cumsum()
})

# Line plot
df.plot(figsize=(12, 6), title='Time Series')
plt.show()

# Multiple plots
fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 2, figsize=(12, 10))

df.plot(ax=axes[0, 0], title='Line Plot')
df.plot.hist(ax=axes[0, 1], bins=20, alpha=0.7, title='Histogram')
df.plot.box(ax=axes[1, 0], title='Box Plot')
df.plot.scatter(x='A', y='B', ax=axes[1, 1], title='Scatter')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

# Bar plot
df_bar = pd.DataFrame({
    'Category': ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D'],
    'Values': [23, 45, 56, 78]
})

df_bar.plot.bar(x='Category', y='Values', figsize=(8, 6))
plt.show()

# Area plot
df.plot.area(figsize=(12, 6), alpha=0.5)
plt.show()

slides.explanation: Pandas .plot(): convenient plotting. df.plot(), df.plot.hist(), df.plot.scatter().

slides.title: üíª Altair: Declarative Visualization

code.snippet:
import altair as alt
import pandas as pd

# Load data
source = alt.load_dataset('cars')

# Scatter plot
chart = alt.Chart(source).mark_circle(size=60).encode(
    x='Horsepower',
    y='Miles_per_Gallon',
    color='Origin',
    tooltip=['Name', 'Origin', 'Horsepower', 'Miles_per_Gallon']
).interactive()

chart

# Bar chart con sorting
bars = alt.Chart(source).mark_bar().encode(
    x=alt.X('Origin:N', sort='-y'),
    y='count()',
    color='Origin'
)

bars

# Line chart con selection
selection = alt.selection_multi(fields=['Origin'])

lines = alt.Chart(source).mark_line().encode(
    x='Year:T',
    y='mean(Acceleration)',
    color='Origin',
    opacity=alt.condition(selection, alt.value(1), alt.value(0.2))
).add_selection(selection)

lines

# Concatenate plots
alt.vconcat(
    chart,
    bars
)

slides.explanation: Altair: declarative, interactive. Grammar of graphics. Elegant API.

slides.title: Best Practices Visualizations
paragraphs: 1. Choose the right library for the use case
xlabel, ylabel, title, legend for context
Plotly/Altair for data exploration, Matplotlib for final visualization.
slides.ironicClosing: Views: 80% of the time choosing colors. 20% plotting data. Priorities.

slides.title: Jupyter Kernel Ecosystem
paragraphs: ‚Ä¢ Program that executes code written in the cells
Scala, Java, Go, Rust, Ruby, PHP, Octave, MATLAB, ...
Kernel menu ‚Üí Change kernel ‚Üí Select language
You can't mix Python and R in the same notebook (use magic %%R)
slides.ironicClosing: Jupyter: polyglot paradise. Python, R, Julia, SQL... now we just need COBOL. Wait...

slides.title: üíª R Kernel (IRkernel)

code.snippet:
# Installazione IRkernel
# In R console:
install.packages('IRkernel')
IRkernel::installspec()  # Install kernel spec

# ===== Poi crea notebook R =====
# New ‚Üí R

# R code in Jupyter
library(ggplot2)

# Data
data(mtcars)

# Plot
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = factor(cyl)), size = 3) +
  geom_smooth(method = 'lm', se = FALSE) +
  labs(title = 'MPG vs Weight',
       x = 'Weight (1000 lbs)',
       y = 'Miles per Gallon',
       color = 'Cylinders') +
  theme_minimal()

# Summary statistics
summary(mtcars)

# Linear model
model <- lm(mpg ~ wt + hp, data = mtcars)
summary(model)

slides.explanation: IRkernel for R. Install R packages, then ggplot2, dplyr, etc. work.

slides.title: üíª SQL in Jupyter (ipython-sql)

code.snippet:
# Installazione
# pip install ipython-sql sqlalchemy

# Load extension
%load_ext sql

# Connect to database
%sql sqlite:///mydatabase.db

# O PostgreSQL
# %sql postgresql://user:password@localhost/dbname

# SQL query (line magic)
%sql SELECT * FROM users LIMIT 5

# SQL query (cell magic)
%%sql
SELECT 
    country,
    COUNT(*) as user_count,
    AVG(age) as avg_age
FROM users
GROUP BY country
ORDER BY user_count DESC
LIMIT 10

# Salva risultato in DataFrame
result = %sql SELECT * FROM users WHERE age > 25
df = result.DataFrame()

# Usa variabili Python in SQL
min_age = 30
%sql SELECT * FROM users WHERE age > :min_age

# Pandas ‚Üí SQL
import pandas as pd
df = pd.DataFrame({'name': ['Alice', 'Bob'], 'age': [25, 30]})
df.to_sql('new_table', engine, if_exists='replace')

slides.explanation: ipython-sql for SQL. %sql line magic, %%sql cell magic. Pandas integration.

slides.title: üíª Multi-language Magics

code.snippet:
# Python notebook, ma esegui R code %load_ext rpy2.ipython # R code in Python notebook %%R library(ggplot2) data(mtcars) ggplot(mtcars, aes(x=wt, y=mpg)) + geom_point() # Pass data Python ‚Üí R import pandas as pd df = pd.DataFrame({'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [4, 5, 6]}) %%R -i df # df ora disponibile in R print(df) plot(df$x, df$y) # Pass data R ‚Üí Python %%R -o result result <- data.frame(a=1:5, b=6:10) # result ora in Python print(result) # pandas DataFrame # ===== Bash ===== %%bash echo "Hello from bash" ls -la # ===== JavaScript ===== %%javascript console.log('Hello from JavaScript'); alert('Jupyter supports JS!'); # ===== HTML ===== %%html

Custom HTML

slides.explanation: rpy2 for R in Python notebook. -i input, -o output. %%bash, %%js, %%html.

slides.title: JupyterLab vs Classic Notebook
paragraphs: ‚Ä¢ One notebook at a time (one tab)
‚Ä¢ Perfect for beginners or simple tasks
‚Ä¢ Terminal, Code console, Built-in text editor
‚Ä¢ JupyterLab: Serious Data Science, complex projects
slides.ironicClosing: Notebook: text editor. JupyterLab: IDE. Both great, choose based on complexity.

slides.title: üíª JupyterLab Features

code.snippet:
# Avvia JupyterLab
jupyter lab

# ===== Features principali =====

# 1. FILE BROWSER (sidebar sinistra)
# - Navigate directories
# - Create, rename, delete files
# - Drag & drop upload

# 2. MULTI-DOCUMENT
# - Multiple notebooks in tabs
# - Split view (drag tab a lato)
# - Arrange layout custom

# 3. TERMINAL
# File ‚Üí New ‚Üí Terminal
# Full bash terminal in browser

# 4. TEXT EDITOR
# Edit .py, .md, .json, etc.
# Syntax highlighting

# 5. CODE CONSOLE
# Connected to notebook kernel
# Test code senza creare celle

# 6. OUTPUT VIEWS
# Right-click output ‚Üí Create New View
# Output in pannello separato

# 7. TABLE OF CONTENTS
# View ‚Üí Show Table of Contents
# Navigazione headings markdown

# 8. DEBUGGER
# View ‚Üí Debugger
# Set breakpoints, step through code

slides.explanation: JupyterLab: file browser, terminal, editor, console. Multi-tab, split view.

slides.title: üíª JupyterLab Debugger

code.snippet:
# Abilitare debugger in JupyterLab
# View ‚Üí Debugger (attiva sidebar destra)

# In cella code:
def calculate_sum(numbers):
    total = 0
    for num in numbers:
        total += num  # Set breakpoint qui (click numero linea)
    return total

result = calculate_sum([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
print(result)

# ===== Debugger controls =====
# - Set breakpoint: Click line number (red dot)
# - Continue: Resume execution
# - Step Over: Execute current line
# - Step Into: Enter function call
# - Step Out: Exit current function

# ===== Inspect variables =====
# Debugger sidebar mostra:
# - Variables panel: Vedi valori correnti
# - Callstack: Function call history
# - Breakpoints: Lista breakpoints attivi
# - Source: Code con highlight

# ===== IPython debugger (alternativa) =====
# Magic command per debugging
import pdb

def buggy_function():
    x = 10
    pdb.set_trace()  # Breakpoint
    y = x / 0  # Error
    return y

buggy_function()

slides.explanation: Visual debugger in JupyterLab. Breakpoints, step-through, inspect variables.

slides.title: üíª JupyterLab Extensions

code.snippet:
# ===== Extension Manager (GUI) =====
# Settings ‚Üí Enable Extension Manager

# 1. jupyterlab-git
pip install jupyterlab-git

slides.title: üíª JupyterLab Shortcuts

code.snippet:
# ===== FILE & LAUNCHER =====
Cmd+Shift+L / Ctrl+Shift+L    # Open Launcher
Cmd+S / Ctrl+S                # Save
Cmd+Shift+S / Ctrl+Shift+S    # Save As
Cmd+W / Ctrl+W                # Close tab

# ===== SIDEBAR =====
Cmd+B / Ctrl+B                # Toggle left sidebar
Cmd+Shift+B / Ctrl+Shift+B    # Toggle right sidebar (debugger)

# ===== TABS & LAYOUT =====
Cmd+Shift+[ / Ctrl+Shift+[    # Previous tab
Cmd+Shift+] / Ctrl+Shift+]    # Next tab
Cmd+K Cmd+‚Üê / Ctrl+K Ctrl+‚Üê   # Split left
Cmd+K Cmd+‚Üí / Ctrl+K Ctrl+‚Üí   # Split right

# ===== COMMAND PALETTE =====
Cmd+Shift+C / Ctrl+Shift+C    # Open command palette
# Search e execute commands

# ===== NOTEBOOK (stessi di classic) =====
Shift+Enter                   # Run cell
A                             # Insert above
B                             # Insert below
DD                            # Delete cell

# ===== TERMINAL =====
File ‚Üí New ‚Üí Terminal         # New terminal
Cmd+K Cmd+Shift+T             # New terminal (shortcut)

slides.explanation: Cmd+Shift+C for command palette. Cmd+B to toggle sidebar. Very customizable.

slides.title: Alternative Cloud
slides.subtitle: Google Colab, Kaggle, Databricks
slides.description: Jupyter in the cloud, zero setup, free GPU

slides.title: Google Colab
paragraphs: What it is: Jupyter Notebook hosted by Google, free of charge
‚Ä¢ Colab Pro ($10/mo) - GPU priority, longer runtime
slides.ironicClosing: Colab: free GPU. Catch: session timeout just when you're about to finish training. Classic.

slides.title: üíª Google Colab Specifics

code.snippet:
# ===== GPU/TPU =====
# Runtime ‚Üí Change runtime type ‚Üí GPU/TPU

# Verifica GPU
import torch
print(torch.cuda.is_available())  # True se GPU disponibile
print(torch.cuda.get_device_name(0))  # Nome GPU

# ===== Mount Google Drive =====
from google.colab import drive
drive.mount('/content/drive')
# Ora accedi: /content/drive/MyDrive/...

# ===== Upload file =====
from google.colab import files
uploaded = files.upload()  # File picker

# ===== Download file =====
files.download('myfile.csv')

# ===== Install packages =====
!pip install package-name
# Packages installati persistono per sessione corrente

# ===== Forms (UI widgets) =====
#@title Parameters { display-mode: "form" }
learning_rate = 0.001 #@param {type:"number"}
model_name = "ResNet50" #@param ["ResNet50", "VGG16", "MobileNet"]
use_pretrained = True #@param {type:"boolean"}

print(f"LR: {learning_rate}, Model: {model_name}")

# ===== Sistema info =====
!nvidia-smi  # GPU info
!cat /proc/cpuinfo  # CPU info
!free -h  # RAM info

slides.explanation: Colab: mount Drive, upload/download, GPU check, forms for UI. Magic commands.

slides.title: Kaggle Notebooks
paragraphs: What it is: Jupyter hosted by Kaggle, focus on Data Science competitions
‚Ä¢ No internet access (security, Kaggle solo datasets)
‚Ä¢ Kaggle: More GPU hours, no internet
slides.ironicClosing: Kaggle: Colab but for competitions. No internet = security. Or paranoia. Both.

slides.title: Other Alternatives
paragraphs: ‚Ä¢ Native Jupyter support in VS Code
slides.ironicClosing: Alternative: too many. The Jupyter ecosystem is a buffet. Choose your base flavors.

slides.title: Extensions & Widgets
slides.subtitle: ipywidgets, voil√†, nbextensions
slides.description: Interactivity and custom UI in notebooks

slides.title: üíª ipywidgets: Interattiva UI

code.snippet:
import ipywidgets as widgets
from IPython.display import display
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Slider
slider = widgets.IntSlider(
    value=50,
    min=0,
    max=100,
    step=1,
    description='Value:'
)
display(slider)

# Button
button = widgets.Button(description='Click me!')
def on_button_click(b):
    print('Button clicked!')
button.on_click(on_button_click)
display(button)

# Dropdown
dropdown = widgets.Dropdown(
    options=['Option 1', 'Option 2', 'Option 3'],
    value='Option 1',
    description='Select:'
)
display(dropdown)

# Interactive plot
@widgets.interact(freq=(1, 10, 0.5), amplitude=(0.1, 2, 0.1))
def plot_sine(freq=1, amplitude=1):
    x = np.linspace(0, 4*np.pi, 100)
    y = amplitude * np.sin(freq * x)
    plt.figure(figsize=(10, 4))
    plt.plot(x, y)
    plt.ylim(-2, 2)
    plt.grid(True)
    plt.show()

# Multiple widgets
slider1 = widgets.FloatSlider(value=1, min=0, max=5, description='A:')
slider2 = widgets.FloatSlider(value=1, min=0, max=5, description='B:')
output = widgets.interactive_output(
    lambda a, b: print(f'Sum: {a+b}'),
    {'a': slider1, 'b': slider2}
)
display(widgets.VBox([slider1, slider2, output]))

slides.explanation: ipywidgets for interactivity. Sliders, buttons, dropdowns. @interact decorator.

slides.title: üíª Voil√†: Notebook ‚Üí Web App

code.snippet:
# Installazione
pip install voila

# Converti notebook in web app (hide code)
voila mynotebook.ipynb

# Apre browser su http://localhost:8866
# Mostra solo output e widgets (no code cells)

# Serve directory
voila notebooks/

# Template custom
voila mynotebook.ipynb --template=dark

# Deploy su Heroku/Binder
# Voil√† pu√≤ essere hostato come web app

# ===== Esempio notebook per Voil√† =====
# mynotebook.ipynb
import ipywidgets as widgets
import pandas as pd
import plotly.express as px

# Load data
df = pd.read_csv('data.csv')

# Dropdown filter
category = widgets.Dropdown(
    options=df['category'].unique(),
    description='Category:'
)

# Interactive plot
def update_plot(cat):
    filtered = df[df['category'] == cat]
    fig = px.bar(filtered, x='name', y='value')
    fig.show()

widgets.interactive(update_plot, cat=category)

# Voil√† rende questo un dashboard interattivo

slides.explanation: Here you go: notebook ‚Üí web app. Hide code, show widgets. Deploy dashboards.

slides.title: üíª Jupyter Notebook Extensions

code.snippet:
# Installazione nbextensions (Notebook classic)
pip install jupyter_contrib_nbextensions
jupyter contrib nbextension install --user

# Enable configurator
jupyter nbextensions_configurator enable --user

# Avvia notebook ‚Üí Nbextensions tab
# GUI per enable/disable extensions

# ===== Popular extensions =====

# 1. Table of Contents (TOC)
# Auto-genera TOC da markdown headings

# 2. ExecuteTime
# Mostra execution time sotto ogni cella

# 3. Variable Inspector
# Inspector variabili (tipo RStudio)

# 4. Collapsible Headings
# Collapse/expand sezioni markdown

# 5. Code Folding
# Fold code blocks

# 6. Hinterland
# Autocomplete automatico (no Tab)

# 7. Scratchpad
# Temporary cell per test

# 8. Snippets Menu
# Template code snippets

# Enable extension via CLI
jupyter nbextension enable toc2/main

# Disable
jupyter nbextension disable toc2/main

slides.explanation: nbextensions for classic Notebook. TOC, ExecuteTime, Variable Inspector. GUI.

slides.title: üíª Custom Styling & Themes

code.snippet:
# ===== JupyterLab Themes =====
# Settings ‚Üí Theme ‚Üí Dark/Light

# Install custom themes
pip install jupyterlab-night
pip install theme-darcula

# Rebuild JupyterLab
jupyter lab build

# ===== Notebook Classic Themes =====
pip install jupyterthemes

# List themes
jt -l

# Apply theme
jt -t chesterish  # Dark theme
jt -t grade3     # Light theme
jt -t onedork    # Atom One Dark

# Customize
jt -t monokai -f fira -fs 11 -nf ptsans -nfs 11 -T -N
# -f: font
# -fs: font size
# -T: toolbar
# -N: name & logo

# Reset to default
jt -r

# ===== Custom CSS =====
# Create: ~/.jupyter/custom/custom.css
.CodeMirror {
    font-family: 'Fira Code', monospace;
    font-size: 14px;
}

.rendered_html h1 {
    color: #2c3e50;
}

slides.explanation: jupyterthemes for styling. Dark/light themes. Custom CSS for full control.

slides.title: üíª nbconvert: Export Formats

code.snippet:
# nbconvert built-in con Jupyter

# ===== HTML (static) =====
jupyter nbconvert --to html notebook.ipynb
# Output: notebook.html

# HTML senza code (solo output)
jupyter nbconvert --to html --no-input notebook.ipynb

# ===== PDF =====
jupyter nbconvert --to pdf notebook.ipynb
# Richiede: LaTeX (MikTeX su Win, MacTeX su Mac)

# ===== Markdown =====
jupyter nbconvert --to markdown notebook.ipynb
# Output: notebook.md + images/

# ===== Python script =====
jupyter nbconvert --to python notebook.ipynb
# Output: notebook.py (solo code cells)

# ===== LaTeX =====
jupyter nbconvert --to latex notebook.ipynb

# ===== Slides (reveal.js) =====
jupyter nbconvert --to slides notebook.ipynb
# Output: notebook.slides.html

# Serve slides
jupyter nbconvert --to slides notebook.ipynb --post serve
# Apre browser con presentazione

# ===== Custom template =====
jupyter nbconvert --to html --template lab notebook.ipynb

# ===== Execute before export =====
jupyter nbconvert --to html --execute notebook.ipynb

slides.explanation: nbconvert: HTML, PDF, Markdown, Python, Slides. --no-input to hide code.

slides.title: üíª Slides with RISE

code.snippet:
# RISE: Reveal.js presentation in Jupyter
pip install RISE

# ===== Configurare slide types =====
# Per ogni cella, toolbar ‚Üí View ‚Üí Cell Toolbar ‚Üí Slideshow

# Slide types:
# - Slide: Main slide
# - Sub-Slide: Sub-slide (down arrow)
# - Fragment: Appear incrementally
# - Skip: Hidden in presentation
# - Notes: Speaker notes

# ===== Avviare presentazione =====
# In JupyterLab/Notebook: Alt+R (o button "Enter/Exit RISE")

# Navigazione:
# - Space/‚Üí: Next
# - Shift+Space/‚Üê: Previous
# - ‚Üë/‚Üì: Sub-slides
# - Esc: Overview mode

# ===== Export slides =====
jupyter nbconvert --to slides notebook.ipynb --post serve

# ===== Tips =====
# - Code cells eseguono live in presentation
# - Interactive widgets funzionano
# - Use markdown per title slides
# - Use fragments per progressive reveal

slides.explanation: RISE for live presentations. Based on Reveal.js. Code runs during the talk.

slides.title: üíª Sharing: nbviewer & GitHub

code.snippet:
# ===== GitHub =====
# GitHub renderizza .ipynb automaticamente
git add notebook.ipynb
git commit -m "Add analysis notebook"
git push

# View su: github.com/user/repo/blob/main/notebook.ipynb

# ‚ö†Ô∏è Best practice:
# - Clear output prima di commit (file size)
# - O commit con output per condivisione

# Clear output
jupyter nbconvert --clear-output --inplace notebook.ipynb

# ===== nbviewer =====
# nbviewer.jupyter.org rende notebook da URL

# 1. Upload notebook su GitHub/Gist
# 2. Copia URL
# 3. Vai a nbviewer.jupyter.org
# 4. Paste URL
# 5. Share link nbviewer

# Direct link:
# https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/user/repo/blob/main/notebook.ipynb

# ===== Binder =====
# mybinder.org - Interactive notebooks da GitHub

# 1. Push notebook + requirements.txt a GitHub
# 2. Vai a mybinder.org
# 3. Paste repo URL
# 4. Launch ‚Üí Interactive notebook in cloud
# 5. Share binder link

# requirements.txt example:
numpy==1.24.0
pandas==2.0.0
matplotlib==3.7.0

slides.explanation: GitHub renders notebooks. nbviewer for sharing. Binder for interactive.

slides.title: Best Practices Sharing
paragraphs: How to run notebooks, where to find data
Download link or script to fetch data
Explain what the notebook does, assumptions, results.
PDF is universal, no setup needed.
slides.ironicClosing: Sharing: Clear output of 500MB git repo. Choose wisely. nbstripout is your friend.

slides.title: ‚úÖ Best Practices Jupyter
paragraphs: ‚Ä¢ Table of contents for long notebooks
‚Ä¢ Before commit/share, ALWAYS restart & run all
‚Ä¢ All imports in the first cell (convention)
‚Ä¢ Granular cells (load data, clean data, plot, etc.)
‚Ä¢ Comments in the code for details
slides.ironicClosing: Best practices: ignore and spend hours debugging an inconsistent notebook. Or follow them and live peacefully.

slides.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è Anti-Patterns to Avoid
paragraphs: ‚ùå Jumping between cells creates inconsistent state
‚úÖ Execute sequentially, restart & run all to verify
‚úÖ Split into multiple notebooks or refactor into .py
‚úÖ Use a .py script instead (notebook is for exploration)
slides.ironicClosing: Anti-patterns: a fast track to tech debt. Notebook becomes legacy code that no one touches.

slides.title: üéØ When to Use Jupyter
paragraphs: ‚Ä¢ Large codebases ‚Üí Proper IDE (VS Code, PyCharm)
slides.ironicClosing: Jupyter: great for exploration. Horrible for production. Know the boundaries, thrive.
